Please have a look at the tweaks I did ... but thank you very much for your PR :-)
@todoubaba please have a look on my response on the mailing list

> @todoubaba please have a look on my response on the mailing list

But you please also see what others have written ;-)
@todoubaba I removed the dependency in develop. It should no longer use beanutils
@chrisdutz @sruehl Thank you all, it's a great project, and a great community.

Hi @todoubaba,
sorry for having wasted your time in preparing a PR ... I do think @sruehl 's solution should be the simpler one. I hope you don't mind that I simply close this PR without merging your changes. Please don't feel discouraged.

And of course we would be super excited if you could describe on the mailinglist, what you are doing with PLC4X. Cause most of us work on PLC4X but don't actually have direct use-cases, we just think that the world needs something like this project. Knowing what it's being used for is a huge motivation boost.

Thanks again,
Chris

@chrisdutz It's OK. I am using PLC4X in a medical device，the host node is an industrial Android screen, and the slave nodes are single axis controllers. The protocol is CANOpen, and the transport is a customized CANTransport over ethernet.
@todoubaba Does commons-lang work with Anadroid? If so then we still can amend this PR to rely on FieldUtils mentioned earlier.
@splatch With my own patch, Plc4j works fine with Android. Not found any issues in commons-lang.

@todoubaba Since you removed beanutils but still had commons-lang on classpath I believe we can get issue solved with `FieldUtils` so you will have "standard" release of PLC4X working under Android, WDYT?
@splatch ... this issue has been resolved as @sruehl already addressed and fixed the issue on the develop branch.

The problem was the usage of the BeanUtils and not the FieldUtils. So by switching on setting the fields in the configs via FIeldUtils (the annotation is field-based anyway) the code should be able to run on Android (As far as I understood it)
Roger, I wasn't clear if we solved it for Lin or not.

@splatch I updated the snapshot from https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/snapshots/org/apache/plc4x/plc4j-spi/0.10.0-SNAPSHOT/plc4j-spi-0.10.0-20220124.174152-1.jar, it works fine with Android, the problem is solved. 

Thank you all.
Thanks for your feedback .. it's highly appreciated.

Hi Sven (hope that's right)

Thank you for this PR ... I had already heard that there were issues with the LOGO devices, but didn't have the time to investigate any further. I'll test your changes against my LOGO as well as against my S7 devices. If the changes don't have any negative effect on the S7, I think it's safe to merge this PR.

Thank you for contributing :)

Chris

Thanks for your contribution! :)

Regarding a knxproj file being added to the project. I would probably suggest not to do that. Even if it's theroretically not a problem. We would be adding a sort-of-binary file to the repo, which might be a problem. But the most important thing is, that it contains the xml descriptors of KNX products. While the project file itself is probably not a problem, these static XML files are probably not licensed under an Apache compatible licence. We would probably get problems with releases if we added such a file. 

If we don't need the static product-descriptors and can live with the project-xml, I would probably opt for manipulating a knxproj file to remove all the stuff that's not a project-xml. In that case I think there probably shouldn't be any issues.
@dependabot rebase
https://github.com/dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase

Hi Chris,

Totally understand the reasons regarding the ets project file not being
added to the repo, kind of limits testing of the parser though. How would
you feel about just adding some 'hand crafted' XML files, just to exercise
the parser?

I've a couple more questions to ask. I'm still experiencing the invalid
decoding of the 2-byte floating point values.. My recollection was you were
going to contact KNX and see if they were aware of this issue, and then I
think we were going to try and progress things with the code generators
together. Was that right?

And secondly, is there a method used elsewhere in PLC4X where it is
possible to specify the local IP to bind to when connecting out? i.e. in
the Knx driver there is no way to specify which network interface to use if
you have multiple on your computer, if there is a prefered way I'm happy to
implement that in the Knx driver. Perhaps this is only relevant to UDP
connections? It's been a fair few years since I've had to write low level
TCP and UDP code.

Many thanks

Darren

I think the commit message is a bit misleading, it is 3.14.1 not 3.14.2, but I'm going to update. Do I remember correctly PLC4X community would like to donate the component to Apache Camel?
thanks for the PR

Hi hongjinlin ... just one question ... as at Apache most communication is done via mailinglists ... could you please subscribe to the dev@plc4x.apache.org mailinglis (by sending an empty email to dev-subscribe@plc4x.apache.org) and tell us a bit on what you are working on?

We're really happy about your PRs and would like to get to know you a bit better :-)

Thanks Otto,

The Pluggy stuff definitely needs some work, I'm not happy with having to register the driver manually, kind of misses the point of using Pluggy.

I spent a bit of time trying to figure it out and moved on to have something that works. I'll take another look.
@dependabot rebase
@dependabot rebase
@hutcheb ... can this PR be closed and the corresponding branch be deleted? I think develop now has a working RTU driver ...
@hutcheb Is this branch still valid? If yes, we would need to rebase it and port the changes back .

I don't think you have to register them manually, I think that they can register themselves using the setuptools / setup config.

So, if we start out with 1 plc4py whl file, it's setup can register all the distributed drivers like.

https://pluggy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/#loading-setuptools-entry-points

Looking at it, there's still a test disabled for OPCUA, which I believe is the cause for the issue in PLC4X-330

` public void multipleThreads()`

However this PR is a failed attempt to fix the jira issue, by changing the port number of the test opc ua server.
I'll delete this PR, but are you still having issues on your mac with this?

Noting the Plc4Py Interop binding will be remove with this merge.

If anyone has a concern we can put it back in if need be.

Yeah found a way forward with adding the plugins to the poetry config.
I've also added an abtract class PlcConnectionLoader, almost feels a bit of a duplicate of the hookspec but I think it is better.

Yeah I've left off some of the docstrings, I've updated most but still left some of the stub files.

I'll rebase and merge it soon
sounds great

> https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/369146/how-to-avoid-bidirectional-class-and-module-dependencies

I liked accepted answer: 

- Hide it with interfaces
- Add an intermediary object

So are you going for Interfaces or a third object?

I think an intermediary 'client' object makes more sense.
I've pulled out the PlcResponse and PlcRequest stuff from the opposite class.
In the Java version there's a PlcRequestContainer which seems to perform a similar function.
The newer versions of the dependency-plugin still produce the false negatives.
